abstract: Marrissa Mayer talks, a little bit, about Google’s health initiative. It doesn’t feature a site with an “I’m feeling Yucky!” button.
snippet: Marrissa Mayer talks, a little bit, about Google’s health initiative. It doesn’t feature a site with an “I’m feeling Yucky!” button.
lead_paragraph: My ears perked up when Web 2.0 host John Battelle said during the conference’s opening that we’d be hearing about Google’s health initiative from vice president of search products and user experience Marissa Mayer. Soon enough, Ms. Mayer was on stage talking about the top 10 things you might see soon from Google Health. They included features like: An “I’m feeling Yucky!” button; people with all of your problems also searched for; Google’s cookie expiration is now based on your expected expiration date; and the Google paternity search. You guessed. Like most top 10 lists, it was all a joke.

headline.main: Google’s Personal Health Record: Coming One of These Days

abstract: The Internet search giant posted profit of $1.07 billion, fueled by strong performance in its search and advertising business.
snippet: The Internet search giant posted profit of $1.07 billion, fueled by strong performance in its search and advertising business.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 18 — Google said its net income jumped nearly 46 percent in the third quarter, topping analysts’ already bullish forecasts.

abstract: Prices for Internet companies are skyrocketing. But this bubble isn’t about the start-ups that can change the world; it is about established Internet companies afraid of Google, and what might be the next Google.
snippet: Prices for Internet companies are skyrocketing. But this bubble isn’t about the start-ups that can change the world; it is about established Internet companies afraid of Google, and what might be the next Google.
lead_paragraph: Brad Stone and Matt Richtel wrote Wednesday on the front page of The Times about the surging values of Internet companies, a trend that evokes the madness of the late 1990s. The values might be mad, but this is a very different world now.

abstract: NearbyNow, a service to help malls put information on products and prices online, wants to draw customers from search engines. But it doesn’t want to drive mall shoppers back to Yahoo or Google.
snippet: NearbyNow, a service to help malls put information on products and prices online, wants to draw customers from search engines. But it doesn’t want to drive mall shoppers back to Yahoo or Google.
lead_paragraph: While more and more stores have found ways to do business, or at least promote themselves online, shopping malls have not found an easy way to get along with the Internet. Their Web sites have had little more than directions and a list of stores.

headline.main: Brokering a Deal, Carefully, Between Malls and the Web

abstract: After promising investors three months ago that it would rein in its rapid hiring, Google added 2,130 employees in the most recent quarter. It happened to offer jobs to 1,000 university graduates.
snippet: After promising investors three months ago that it would rein in its rapid hiring, Google added 2,130 employees in the most recent quarter. It happened to offer jobs to 1,000 university graduates.
lead_paragraph: Move over, Bureau of Engraving and Printing. Google seems to be the best at printing money these days.

headline.main: Google Promises Again to Swear Off Binge Hiring
